Deale how thou wilt: that that I never feele,
I'le never feare. Yet by the honour of a Souldiour,
I hold thee truly Noble. How these things will looke,
And how their bloods will curdle? play on children,
You shall have pap anon. O thou grand foole,
That thou knowest, but thy fortune— Musick done.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Peace, good Madam,
Stop her mouth Dinant, it sleeps yet, 'pray' be wary,
Dispatch, I cannot endure this misery,
I can heare nothing more; I'le say my praiers,
And downe againe— Whistle within.
A thousand larums, fall upon my quarter,
Heaven send me off; When I ly keeping courses.
Pl— o' your fumbling Dinant; how I shake?
'Tis still againe. Would I were in the Indies. Exit Cler.

div.stage: Enter Dinant, and Lamira. A light within.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Why doe ye use me thus? thus poorely? basely?
Worke me into a hope, and then destroy me?
Why did you send for me? this new way traine me?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Madman, a fool, & fals man, now Ile shew thee man

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: 'Pray' put your light out.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: No I'le hold it thus,
That all chast eyes, may see thy lust, and scorne it,
Tell me but this, when you first doted on me,
And made suite to enjoy me, as your wife,
Did you not hold me honest?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Yes, most vertuous.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: And did not that appeare, the onely lustre
That made me worth your love, and admiration?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I must confesse—

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Why would you deale so basely?
So like a thiefe? a villaine?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Peace, good Madam.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I'le speake aloud too; thus maliciously,
Thus breaking all the rules of honestie,
Of honour, and of truth, for which I lov'd you,
For which, I call'd you servant, and admir'd you,
To steale that jewell, purchas'd by another
Piously set in Wedlock, even that Jewell,
Because it had no flame, you held unvaluable:
Can he that has lov'd good, doat on the divell?
For he that seekes a whore, seeks but his agent:
Or am I of so wild, and low of blood,
So nurs'd in infamies?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I doe not thinke so,
And I repent.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: That will not serve your turne, sir.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: It was your treaty drew me on.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: But it was your villany,
Made you pursue it: I drew you but to try
How much a man, and nobly you durst stand,
How well you had deserv'd the name of vertuous;
But you, like a wild torrent, mix'd with all
Beastly and base affections came floating on,
Swelling your poison'd billowes—

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Will you betray me?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: To all the miseries, a vext woman may.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Let me but out,
Give me but roome to tosse my sword about me,
And I will tell you, y'are a treacherous woman,
O that I had but words!

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: They will not serve you.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: But two-edg'd words to cut thee; a Lady traytor?
Perish by a proud puppet? I did you too much honour,
To tender you my love, too much respected you,
To thinke you worthy of my worst embraces.
Goe, take your groome, and let him dally with you,
Your greasie groome; I scorne to impe your lame stock,
You are not faire, nor handsome, I lyed loudly.
This tongue abus'd you, when it spoke you beauteous.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Tis very well, 'tis brave.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Put out your light,
Your lascivious eyes, are flames enough
For fooles to find you out: a Lady plotter?
Must I begin, your sacrifice of mischiefe?
I and my friend, the first fruits of that blood,
You and your honourable Husband aime at?
Crooked and wretched you are both.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: To you, sir,
Yet to the eye of Justice, streight as Truth.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Is this a womans love? a womans mercy?
Do you professe this seriously? doe you laugh at me?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Pl— light upon your scornes, upon your flatteries
Upon your tempting faces, all destructions:
A bedrid Winter hang upon your cheekes,
And blast, blast, blast, those buds of pride that point you;
Death in your eyes to fright men from these dangers.
Raise up your trophy Cleremont.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: What a vengeance ayle you?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: What dismall noise, is there, no honour in you?
Cleremont, we are betraied, betraied, sold by a woman,
Deale bravely for thy selfe.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This comes of rutting:
Are we made stales to one another?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Yes, we are undone, lost.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You shall pay for't grey-beard:
Vp up, you sleep your last else. Lights above, two Servants and Anabell.

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.l: No not yet, sir,
Lady, looke up: would you have wrong'd this beauty?
Wake so tender a Virgin, with rough tearmes?
You weare a sword; we must entreat you leave it.

sp.speaker: 2 Serv.
sp.l: Fy sir, so sweet a Lady?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Was this my bed-fellow? pray give me leave to look,
I am not mad yet, I may be, by and by.
Did this ly by me?
Did I feare this? is this a cause to shake at?
Away with me for shame, I am a rascall.

div.stage: Enter Champernell, Beaupre, Verdoone, Laimra, Anabel, Cleremont, and two Servants.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I am amaz'd too.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: We'll recover you.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: You walk like Robin-good-fellow, all the house over
And every man afraid of you.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: 'Tis well Lady.
The honour of this deed, will be your owne,
The world shall know your bounty.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: What shall we doe with 'em?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Geld me,
For 'tis not fit I should be a man againe,
I am an Asse, a Dog.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Take your revenges,
You know my Husbands wrongs, and your owne losses.

sp.speaker: Anab.
sp.l: A brave man, an admirable brave man;
Well, well, I would not be so tried again;
A very handsome proper gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Will you let me ly by her, but one houre more,
And then hang me?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Wee wait your malice, put your swords home bravely,
You have reason to seeke blood.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Not as you are Noble.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Hands off and give them liberty, onely disarm 'em.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: We have done that already.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: You are welcome gentlemen,
I am glad my house, has any pleasure for you,
I keep a couple of Ladies here, they say faire,
And you are young, and handsome gentlemen;
Have you any more mind to Wenches?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: To be abus'd too? Lady, you might have help'd this,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Sir now 'tis past, but 't may be I may stand,
Your friend hereafter, in a greater matter.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Never whilst you live.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You cannot tell— now sir a parting hand.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Downe and Roses:
Well, I may live to see you again. A dull rogue,
No revelation in thee.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Were you well frighted?
Were your fitts, from the heart, of all colds and colours?
That's all your punishment.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: It might have bin all yours,
Had not a blockhead undertaken it.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Your swords you must leave to these gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: And now, when you dare fight,
We are on even Ice againe.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: 'Tis well:
To be a Mistris, is to be a monster,
And so I leave your house, and you for ever.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Leave your wild lusts, and then you are a master.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: You may depart too.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I had rather stay here.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Faith we shall fright you worse.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Not in that manner,
There's five hundred crownes, fright me but so againe.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Come Cleremont, this is the houre of foole.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Wiser the next shall be or we'll to schoole. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: How coolely these hot gallants are departed?
Faith cousin 'twas unconscionably done,
To ly so still and so long.

sp.speaker: Anab.
sp.l: 'Twas your pleasure,
If 'twere a fault I may hereafter mend.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: O, My best Wife.
Take now what course thou wilt, and lead what life.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: The more trust you commit, the more care still,
Goodnesse and vertue, shall attend my will.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Let's laugh this night out now & count our gains,
We have our honours home, and they their paines.

div.head: Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: It holds, they will goe thither.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: To their Summer house?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Thither i'th' evening, and which is the most infliction,
Onely to insult upon our miseries.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Are you provided?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Throughly?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Throughly.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Basta enough, I have your mind, I wil not faile you.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: At such an houre.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Have I a memorie?
A Cause, and Will to doe? thou art so sullen—

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: And shall be, till I have a faire reparation.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I have more reason, for I scaped a fortune,
Which if I come so neare againe: I say nothing,
But if I sweat not in another fashion—
O, a delicate Wench.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: 'Tis certaine a most handsome one.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And me thought the thing was angry with it self too
It lay so long concealed but I must part with you,
I have a scene of mirth, to drive this from my heart,
And my houre is come.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Misse not your time.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I dare not. Exeunt severally.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I presume, sir, you now need no instruction,
But fairely know, what belongs to a Gentleman;
You beare your Uncles cause.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Doe not disturbe me,
I understand my cause, and the right carriage.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Be not too bloody.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: As I find my enemy; if his sword bite,
If it bite, sir, you must pardon me.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: No doubt he is valiant,
He durst not undertake else,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Hee's most welcome,
As he is most valiant, he were no man for me else.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: But say he should relent.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Hee dies relenting,
I cannot helpe it, he must die relenting,
If he pray, praying ipso facto, praying,
Your honourable way, admits no prayer,
And if he sight, he falls, there's his quiet us.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Y'are nobly punctuall, let's retire and meet 'em,
But still, I say, have mercy.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: I say, honour. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Champernell, Lamira, Anabell, Beaupre, Verdoone, Charlote and a servant.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Will not you goe sweet-heart?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Goe? I'le fly with thee,
I stay behind?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: My Father will be there too,
And all our best friends,

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: And if we be not merry,
We have hard lucke, Lady.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: Faith let's have a kind of play.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: What shall it be?

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: The story of Dinant.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: With the merry conceits of Cleremont,
His fitts and Fevers.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: But I'le lie still no more.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: That, as you make the Play, 'twill be rare sport,
And how 'twill vex my gallants, when they heare it?
Have you given order for the Coach?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: My easie Nag, and padd.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: 'Tis making ready.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Where are your horses?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Ready at an houre, sir: we'll not be last.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Fy, what a night shall we have?
A roaring, merry night.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: We'll fly at all, sir.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I'le fly at thee too, finely, and so ruffle thee,
I'le try your Art, upon a Country pallet.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Brag not too much, for feare I should expect it,
Then if you faile—

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Thou saiest too true, we all talke,
But let's in, and prepare, and after dinner
Begin our mirthfull pilgrimage.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: He that's sad,
A crab-fac'd Mistris cleave to him for this yeare. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Since it cannot be the Judge—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: 'Tis a great deale better.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: You are sure, he is his kinsman? a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: As arrant a gentleman, and a brave fellow,
And so neare to his blood—

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: It shall suffice,
I'le set him further off, I'le give a remove
Shall quit his kindred, I'le lopp him.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Will ye kill him?

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: And there were no more cosins in the world I kil him,
I do mean, sir, to kill all my Lords kindred.
For every Cause a cousin.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: How if he have no more cousins.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: The next a kin then, to his Lordships favour,
The man he smiles upon.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why this is vengeance, horrid, and dire.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I love a dire revenge:
Give me the man, that will all others kill,
And last himselfe,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You stole that resolution.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I had it in a Play, but that's all one,
I woo'd see it done.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Come, you must be more mercifull.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: To no Lords cosins in the world, I hate 'em;
A Lords cosin to me is a kind of Cocatrice,
If I see him first, he dies.
A strange Antipathy,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: What think you of their Neeces?

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: If I like 'em,
They may live, and multiply; 'tis a cold morning.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: 'Tis sharpe indeed; you have broke your fast.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: No verily.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Your valour would have ask'd a good foundation.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Hang him, I'le kill him fasting.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Here they come,
Beare your selfe in your language, smooth and gently,
When your swords argue.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: 'Pray sir spare your precepts.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I have brought you sir—

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: 'Tis very well, no words,
You are welcome, sir.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I thanke you, sir, few words.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I'le kill you for your Uncles sake.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I love you,
I'le cut your throat, for your owne sake.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I esteeme of you.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Let's render 'em honest, and faire, gentlemen,
Search my friend, I'le search yours.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: That's quickly done.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You come with no spells, nor witchcrafts?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I come fairely, to kill him honestly.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Hang Spells, and Witchcrafts,
I come to kill my Lords Nephew like a gentleman,
And so I kisse his hand.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: This doublet is too stiffe.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Off woo't, I hate it,
And all such fortifications, feele my skin,
If that be stiffe, flea that off too.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: 'Tis no soft one.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Off, woo't, I say:
I'le fight with him, like a flead Catt.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You are well, you are well. Put off.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You must uncase too.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Yes, sir.
But tell me this, why should I mix mine honour
With a fellow, that has ne'r a lace in's shirt?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: That's a maine point, my friend has two.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That's true, sir.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: Base and degenerate cousin, doest not thou know
An old, and tatter'd colours, to the enemy,
Is of more honour, and shewes more ominous?
This shirt, five times, victorious I have fought under,
And cut through squadrons, of your curious Cut-workes,
As I will doe through thine, shake, and be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This is unanswerable.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: But may I fight, with a foule shirt?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Most certaine, so it be a fighting shirt,
Let it be ne'r so foule, or lowsie, Caesar wore such a one.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Saint Denis then: I accept your shirt.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Not so forward, first you must talke,
'Tis a maine point, of the French method,
Talke civilly, and make your cause Authentique.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: No weapon must be neare you, nor no anger.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: When you have done, then stir your resolutions,
Take to your Weapons bravely.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: 'Tis too cold;
This for a Summer fight.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Not for a world, you should transgresse the rules.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: 'Tis peevish weather,
I had rather fight without.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: An 'twere in a river.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Where both stood up to th' chins.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Then let's talke quickly,
Pl— o' this circumstance.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Are the Horses come yet?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yes certaine: give your swords to us, now civilly.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: We'll stand a while off; take the things, & leave 'em,
You know when, and let the children play:
This is a dainty time of yeare for puppies,
Would the old Lord were here.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: He would dy with laughter.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I am sorry I have no time, to see this game out,
Away, away.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Here's like to be a hot fight,
Call when y'are fit. Ex. Cler. and Gent.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Why look you sir, you seem to be a gentleman,
And you come in honour of your Uncle, boh, boh, 'tis very cold;
Your Uncle has offer'd me some few affronts,
Past flesh and blood to beare: boh, boh, wondrous cold.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: My Lord, mine Uncle, is an honourable man,
And what he offers, boh, boh, cold indeed,
Having made choice of me, an unworthy kinsman,
Yet, take me with you: boh, boh, pestlence cold,
Not altogether.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Boh, boh, I say altogether.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: You say you know not what then: boh, boh, sir.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: Sir me with your sword in your hand;
You have a scurvy Uncle, you have a most scurvy cause,
And you are— boh, boh.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Boh, boh, what?

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: A shitten scurvy Cousin.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: Our Swords? our swords?
Thou art a dog, and like a dog: our swords?

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: Our weapons gentlemen: ha? wher's your second?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Where's yours?

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: So ho? our weapons?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Wa, ha, ho, our weapons?
Our Doublets and our weapons, I am dead.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: Firsts? second? third? a pl— be woo' you gentlemen

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Are these the rules of honour? I am starv'd.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: They are gone, and we are here; what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: O for a couple of faggots.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Hang a couple of faggots;
Dar'st thou take a killing cold with me?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I have it already.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Rogues, theeves, boh boh, run away with our Doublets?
To fight at Buffets now, 'twere such a May-game.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: There were no honour in't, p— on't, 'tis scurvy.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Or to revenge my wrongs at fifty-cuffes.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: My Lord, mine Uncles cause, depend on Boxes?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Let's goe in quest, if ever we recover 'em.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I, come, our colds together, and our doublets.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: Give me thy hand; thou art a valiant gentleman.
I say, if ever we recover 'em—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Let's get into a house and warme our hearts.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: There's ne'r a house within this mile, beat me,
Kick me, and beat me as I goe, and I'le beat thee too,
To keepe us warme; if ever we recover 'em—
Kick hard, I am frozen: so, so, now I feele it.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I am dull yet.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: I'le warme thee I'le warme thee.— Gentlemen,
Rogues, theeves, theeves: run, now I'le follow thee. Exeūt.

div.stage: Enter Vertaigne, Champernell Beaupre, Verdoone, Lamira, Annabell. Charlote, Nurse.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Use legs, and have legs.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: You that have legs say so,
I put my one to too much stresse.

sp.speaker: Verdo.
sp.l: Your herse, sir,
Will meet you within halfe a mile,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I like
The walke so well, I should not misse my Coach,
Though it were further. Annabell thou art sad:
What ayles my Niece?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Shee's still devising, sister,
How quietly her late bed-fellow lay by her.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Old as I am, he would have startled me,
Nor can you blame her.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Had I ta'ne her place.
I know not, but I feare, I should ha' shreek'd,
Though he had never offer'd—

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Out upon thee,
Thou wouldst have taught him.

sp.speaker: Charlote.
sp.l: I thinke, with your pardon,
That you wish now you had.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I am glad. I yeild you Cornet. Musicke within.
Such ample scope of mirth.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Nay, be not angrie,
There's no ill meant: ha? Musique, and choice musique?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: 'Tis near us in the Grove what courteous bounty
Bestowes it on us? my dancing daies are done;
Yet I would thanke the giver, did I know him.

sp.speaker: Verdo.
sp.l: 'Tis questionlesse, some one of your own Village,
That hearing of your purpos'd journey thither,
Prepares it for your entertainment, and
The honour of my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I thinke rather,
Some of your Lordships Clyents.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: What say you Cousin?
If they should prove your Suitors?

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: That's most likely.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: I say, if you are noble, be't who will;
Goe presently and thanke 'em: I can jump yet,
Or tread a measure.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Like a Millers Mare.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.l: I warrant you well enough to serve the Country,
I'le make one, and lead the way. Exit.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Doe you note,
How zealous the old Crone is?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: And you titter
As eagerly as she: come sweet, we'll follow,
No ill can be intended. Mus. ends.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I ne'r fear'd yet. Exeunt.

lg.head: Song in the Wood.
lg.l: THis way, this way, come and heare,
You that hold, these pleasures deare,
Fill your eares, with our sweet sound,
Whilst we melt the frozen ground:
This way come, make hast ô faire,
Let your cleare eyes gild the ayer;
Come and blesse us with your sight,
This way, this way seeke delight.

div.stage: Enter a company of Gentlemen, like Ruffians.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: They are ours but draw them on a little further
From the foot-path into the neighbouring thicket,
And we may do't, as safe, as in a Castle.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: They follow still; the President, Vertaigne
Comes on a-pace, and Champernell limps after;
The women, as if they had wings, and walk't
Upon the ayre, fly to us.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: They are welcome,
We'll make 'em sport; make a stand here, all know
How we are to proceed.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: We are instructed. Still Musick within.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: One straine or two more. Gent. off.
sp.stage: Enter Vertaigne, Champernell, Beaupre Verdoone, Lamira, Anabell, Nurse, Charlote.
sp.l: Excellent, they are come,

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: We cannot misse, in such a businesse, yet
Mine eare ne'r fail'd me. Musick for the Dance.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Would we were at it once,
I doe not walke, but dance.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: You shall have dancing.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Begin, and when I give the word—

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: No more.
Weare instructed. Dance.

sp.speaker: Beaupre.
sp.l: But win us fairely— Now.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: O sir, We do not come to try your valour,
But to possess you, yet we use you kindly
In that, like English theeves, wee kill you not,
But are contented with the spoile.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Oh heaven!
How hath mine age deserv'd this?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Hell confound it,
This comes of walking; had I kept my legs,
My legs in my good house, my Armour on,
My Staffe in my rest, and this good sword too, friend,
How I would breake and scatter these.

sp.speaker: All Gent.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Doe you scorne me rogues?

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.l: Nay, Gentlemen, kind gentlemen,
Or honest keepers of these woods, but heare me,
Be not so rough; if you are taken with
My beauty, as it hath bin worth the seeking,
Some one or two of you, try me in private,
You shall not find me squeamish.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Doe not kill me,
And doe your worst, I'le suffer.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Peace vile creatures.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Do you know me, or my place that you presume not
To touch my person?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: If you are well, rest so,
Provoke not angry waspes.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: You are Waspes indeed,
Never created to yeild Wax, or honey,
But for your Countries torment, yet are, if men,
As you seeme such in shape, if true borne French-men,
How ever want compells you to these courses,
Rest satisfied with what you can take from us,
(These Ladies honours, and our liberties safe)
We freely give it.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: You give but our owne.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Looke on these grey haires, as you would be old,
Their teares, as you would have yours to find mercy,
When Justice shall o'retake you.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Looke on me,
Looke on me rascalls, and learne of me too,
That have bin in some part of your profession,
Before that most of you ere suck'd I know it,
I have rode hard, and late too.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Take heed, sir.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Then use me, like a brother of the trade,
For I have been at Sea, as you on land are,
Restore my Matrimony undefil'd,
Wrong not my Neece. and for our gold or silver,
If I pursue you, hang me.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.l: 'Tis well offer'd,
And as I said, sweet gentlemen, with sowre faces,
If you are high, and want some sport, or so,
(As living without action here, you may doe)
Forbeare their tender grissells, they are meate
Will wash away, there is no substance in it,
We that are expert in the game, and tough to,
Will hold you play.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: This hen longs to be troden.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Lackey my horse.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This way, I heard the cries
Of distress'd women.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Stand upon your guard.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Who's here? my witty, scornfull Lady-plot?
In the hands of ruffians,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And my fine cold virgin,
That was insensible of man, and woman?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Justice too,
Without a sword to guard it self?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And valour with its hands bound?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: And the great Souldier dull?
Why this is strange;

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Dinant as thou art noble—

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: As thou art valiant Cleremont.—

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: As ever I appear'd lovely—

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: As you ever hope,
For what I would give gladly—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Pretty conjurations,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: All injuries, a little laied behind you

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Shew your selves men, and help us

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Though your many
And grosse abuses of me, should more move me
To triumph in your miseries then releive you,—
Yet that hereafter, you may know that I
The scorne and despis'd Dinant, knows what does.
Belong to honour, thus—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I will say little, Fight.
Speake thou for me,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: 'Tis bravely fought,

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Brave tempers,
To doe thus for their enemies.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: They are lost yet,

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: You that would rescue others, shall now feele
What they were borne to,

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.p: Hurry them away. Exit. Manent Vertaigne, and Champernell.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: That I could follow them,

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: I only can lament my fortune, and desire of heaven
A little life for my revenge.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: The provost,
Shall fire the woods, but I will find e'm out,
No cave, no rocke, nor hell shall keepe them from
My searching vengeance.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: O cold! o fearfull cold! plague of all seconds,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: O for a pint of burnt wine, or a sip
Of aqua fortis.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: The rogues have met with these two
Upon my life and robd 'em

sp.speaker: La. Wr.
sp.l: As you are honourable Gentlemen,
Impart unto a couple of cold combatants,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: My Lord, mine uncle as I live,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Pox take him.
How that word, has warm'd my mouth?

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Why how now Cousen?
Why, why? and where man, have you bin? at a Poulters
That you are cass'd thus like a rabbet? I could laugh now,
And I shall laugh, for all I have lost my Children,
Laugh monstruously

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: What are they?

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Give me leave Sir,
Laugh more and more, never leave laughing,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Why Sir?

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Why 'tis such a thing I smell it Sir, I smell it,
Such a ridiculous thing,—

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Do you laugh at me my Lord?
I am very cold, but that should not be laught at,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: If he had his doublet.—
And his sword by his side, as a Gentleman ought to have

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Peace Mounsier Sampson.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Come hither little Gentleman,

sp.speaker: La wr.
sp.l: Base is the slave commanded: come to me

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: This is the little advocate

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: What advocate?

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: The little advocate that sent me a challenge,
I told you that my Nephew under tooke it,
And what t'was like to prove: now you see the issue.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Is this the little Lawyer?

sp.speaker: La. wr.
sp.l: You have a sword Sir,
And I have none, you have a doublet too,
That keepes you warme, and makes you merry,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: If your Lordship knew.
The nature, and the noblenesse of the Gentleman,
Though he shew sleight here, & at what gusts of danger
His manhood has arrived,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Bee't then.
Mens faces are foolish,
And often head long, over run their fortunes,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: That little Lawyer, would so pricke his eares up,
And bite your honour by the nose.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Say you so Sir?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.p: So niggle about your grave shins Lord Vertaigne too

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: No more sweet Gentleman, no more of that Sir,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: I will have more, I must have more.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Out with it.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Nay he is as brave a fellow.—

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Have I caught you? Strike him downe.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Doe not kill him, doe not kill him.
No no, no, I will not

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Doe you peepe againe, downe downe proud heart

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: O valour,
Looke up brave friend, I have no meanes to rescue thee,
My Kingdome for a sword,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I'll sword you presently,
I'll claw your skin-coate too.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Away good Samson,
You goe to grasse els instantly,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: But doe not murder my brave friend

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Not one word,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: If you doe sirra,—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Must I goe off dishonour'd?
Adversity tries valour, so I leave thee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Are you a Lawyer Sir?

sp.speaker: La-Wr.
sp.l: I was, I was Sir,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Nay never looke, your Lawyers pate is broken
And your litigious blood, about your eares sirra,
Why doe you fight and snarle?

sp.speaker: La. Wr.
sp.l: I was possest.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Ile disposesse you.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: La-Wr.
sp.l: Et tu Brute.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Beate him no more.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Alas Sir I must beate him,
Beate him into his businesse agen, he will be lost els.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Then take your way,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Ly still, and doe not struggle,

sp.speaker: La-Wr.
sp.l: I am patient,
I never saw my blood before, it jades me,
I have no more heart now then a goose.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Why sirra, why do you leave your trade, your trade of living,
And send your challenges like thunderbolts,
To men of honour'd place?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: I understand Sir,
I never understood, before your beating,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Does this worke on you?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Doe you thanke me for't?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: As well as a beaten man can,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: And doe you promise me,
To fall close to your trade againe? leave brawling

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: If you will give me leave and life,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: And aske this noble man forgivenesse?

sp.speaker: La-Wr.
sp.l: Hartily.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Rise then, and get you gone, and let me heare of you
As of an Advocate new vampt; no more words,
Get you off quickly, and make no murmurs
I shall pursue you else,

sp.speaker: La-Wr.
sp.l: I have done sweet Gentlemen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: But we forget our selves, our Friends and Children

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Wee'l raise the coūtry first, then take our fortunes.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Shall I entereate for what I may command?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Thinke on my birth,

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Here I am only Noble.
A King, and thou in my dominions foole,
A subject and a slave.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Be nor a Tyrant;
A ravisher of honour, gentle Sir,
And I will thinke ye such, and on my knees,
As to my Soveraigne, pay a Subjects duty,
With prayers and teares,

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: I like this humble carriage.
I will walke by, but kneele you still and weepe too,
It shewes well, while I meditate on the prey,
Before I seize it.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Is there no mercie, heaven?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Not kisse you?
I will kisse and kisse againe,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Savage villaine!
My Innocence be my strength, I doe defie thee,
Thus scorne and spit at thee; will you come on Sir,
You are hot, there is a cooler,

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: A virago?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: No, lothsome Goate, more, more I am that Goddesse,
That here with whippes of steele in hell hereafter
Scourge rape and theft,

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: I'll try your deity,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: My chastity, and this knife held by a Virgin,
Against thy lust thy sword and thee a Beast.
Call on for the encounter.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: Now what thinke you? Throwes her and takes. her Knife.
Are you a Goddesse?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: In me their power suffers,
That should protect the Innocent,

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: I am all fire,
And thou shall quench it, and serve my pleasures,
Come partner in the spoile and the reward,
Let us enjoy our purchase

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O Dinant!
O Heaven! o Husband!

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: O my Cleremont!

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Two are our slaves they call on, bring 'em forth
As they are chaind together let them see
And suffer in the object.

div.stage: Enter Dinant and Cleremont bound. By the rest of the Gent.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: While we sit
And without pitty heare 'em

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: By my life,
I suffer more for thee then for my self,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Be a man Cleremont, and looke upon 'em,
As such that not alone abus'd our service,
Fed us with hopes most bitter indigestion,
But when love faild, to draw on further mischeif,
The baites they laied for us; were our owne honours,
Which thus hath made us slaves too, worse then slaves

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: He dies

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Pray hold, give him a little respite,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I see you now beyond expression wretched,
The wit you bragd of, foold, that boasted honour,
As you beleev'd compass'd with walls of brasse,
To guard it sure, Subject to be o're throwne
With the least blast of lust.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: A most sad truth.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: That confidence which was not to be shaken
In a perpetuall fever, and those favours,
Which with so strong, and Ceremonious duty
Your lover and a Gentleman long sought for,
Sought, sued, and kneeld in vaine for, must you yeild up
To a licentious villaine, that will hardly,
Allow you thanks for't

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Something I must say too,
And to you pretty one, though crying one;
To be hangd now, when these worshipful benchers please
Though I know not their faces that condemne me,
A little startles me, but a man is nothing,
A Maydenhead is the thing, the thing all aime at;
Doe not you wish now, and wish from your heart too,
When scarce sweet with my feares, I long lay by you
Those feares you and your good Aunt put upon me,
To make you sport you had giuen a little hint,
A touch or so, to tell me I was mortall,
And by a mortall woman?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Pray you no more

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: If I had loos'd that virgin Zone, observe me,
I would have hired the best of all our Poets
To have sung so much, and so well in the honour
Of that nights joye, that Ovids afternoone,
Nor his Corvina should againe be mentioned,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I doe repent, and wish I had,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That's comfort,
But now.—

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Another that will have it offer'd,
Compell it to be offer'd, shall enjoye it.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: A rogue, a ruffian.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: As you love your throat,—

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Away with them.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: O Cleremont!

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O Dinant!

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I can but add your sorrowes to my sorrowes,
Your feares to my feares,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: To your wishes mine.
This slave may prove unable to performe,
Till I performe the taske that I was borne for,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Amen, amen.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Drag the slaves hence, for you
A while I'll locke you up here study all wayes
You can to please me, or the deed being done,
You are but dead.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: This strong vault shall conteine you
There thinke how many for your maydenhead
Have pin'd away, and be prepared to loose it
With penitence.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: No humane help can save you.

sp.speaker: Ladyes.
sp.l: Helpe, helpe?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: You cry in vaine, rockes cannot heare you.

div.head: Scena Prima.
div.stage: A Horrid noise of Musique within, Enter one and opens the Chamber doore, in which Lamira and Anabell were shut, they in all feare.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O Cousen how I shake, all this long night,
What frights and noises we have heard still they encrease
The villaines put on shapes to torture us,
And to their Divells forme such preparations
As if they were a hatching new dishonours,
And fatall ruine, past dull mans invention
Goe not too far and pray good Cousen Anabell
Harke a new noise. A strange Musick. Sackbut & Troup musick.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: They are exquisite in mischeif.
I will goe on this roome gives no protection,
More then the next what's that? how sad and hollow,
The sound comes to us. Theeves peeping. Lowder.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Groning? or singing is it?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: The wind I think, murmuring amongst old rooms

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Now it growes lowder sure some sad presage
Of our fowle losse— peepe—, looke now they peepe,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Pox peepe 'em.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O give them gentle language,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Give 'em rats-bane. Peepe above.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Now they are above

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I would they were i th Center,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Thou art so foolish desperate,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Since we must loose.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Call 'em brave fellowes, Gentlemen,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Call 'em rogues,
Rogues as they are, rude rogues, uncivill villaines

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Look an thou woot, beware dost thou feele the danger?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Till the danger feele me, this will I talke still,
And worse when that comes too; they cannot eate me
This is a punishment, upon our owne prides,
Most justly laied; we must abuse brave Gentlemen,
Make 'em tame fooles & hobby-horses, laugh & jeere at
Such men too, and so handsome and so Noble,
That howsoere we seem'd to carry it
Woo'd 'twer to doe againe,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I doe confesse cousen,
It was too harsh, too foolish

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Doe you feele it?
Doe you find it now? take heed ot'h punishment,
We might have had two gallant Gentlemen,
Proper young, o how it tortures me
Two Divells now, two rascalls two and twenty

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O thinke not so

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Nay an we scape so modestly—

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: May we be worthy any eyes, or knowledge,
When we are used thus?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Why not? why doe you cry!
Are we not women still? what were we made for?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: But thus, thus basely—

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: 'Tis against our wills,
And if there come a thousand so,—

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Out on thee,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You are a foole, what we cannot resist,
Why should we greive and blush for? there be women,
And they that beare the name of excellent women
Would give their whole estates, to meete this fortune

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Harke, a new noise. New found within.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Let 'em goe on, I feare not,
If wrangling fighting and scratching cannot preserve me
Why so be it Cousen; if I be ordain'd
To breed a race of rogues.—

div.stage: Enter foure over the stage with Beaupre and Verdoone bound and halters about their necks.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: They come

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Be firme,
They are wellcom.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: What mask of death is this? O my deare Brother

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: My coose to; why now y'are glorious villaines

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O shall we loose our honours?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Let 'em goe,
When death prepares the way, they are but Pageants
Why must these dye?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Lament your owne misfortunes
We perish happily before your ruines,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Has mischeif ne'r a tongue?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Yes foolish woman,
Our Captaines will is death.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You dare not doe it
Tell thy base boisterous Captaine what I say,
Thy lawlesse Captaine that he dares not;
Doe you laugh you rogue? you pamperd rogue?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Good Sir,
Good Cousen gently, as y'are a Gentleman,—

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: A gentleman? a slave a dog the devills harbinger

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Sir as you had a mother,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: He a Mother?
Shame not the name of mother, a she Beare
A bloody old woolf bitch, a woman Mother?
Lookes that rude lumpe, as if he had a mother?
Intreat him? hang him, do thy worst thou darst not,
Thou dar'st not wrong their lives, thy Captain dares not
They are persons of more price

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What ere we suffer
Let not your angers wrong you,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You cannot suffer.
The men that doe this deed must live i'th moone
Free from the gripe of Justice.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Is it not better?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Is it not better? let 'em goe on like rascalls
And put false faces on; they dare not doe it;
Flatter such scabbs of nature,

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Woman, woman
The next worke is with you,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Unbind those Gentlemen,
And put their fatall fortunes, on our neckes.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: As you have mercy doe;

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: As you are monsters.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Fright us no more with shipwrack of our honours
Nor if there be a guilt by us committed
Let it endanger those,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I say they dare not,
There be a thousand gallouses, yee rogues,
Tortures, ye bloody rogues wheeles,

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: A way.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Stay,
Stay and I'll flatter too: good sweet fac'd Gentlemen
You excellent in honesty; o kinsmen!
O Noble kinsmen!

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Away with 'em. Exit Verta. Beaup. and Gent.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Stay yet
The Devill and his lovely dam walke with you,
Come fortify your self, if they doe dy,
Which all their ruggednesse, cannot rack into me
They cannot find an houre more Innocent,
Nor more friends to revenge 'em.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Now stand constant,
For now our tryalls come,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This beauties mine
Your minute moves not yet,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: She sinkes if Christian,
If any sparke of noble heate.—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Rise Lady
And fearelesse rise, there's no dishonour meant you,
Doe you know my tongue?

sp.speaker: Ana,
sp.l: I have heard it,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Marke it better
I am one that loves you, fairely, nobly loves you
Looke on my face?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: O Sir?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: No more words, softly
Hearke, but hearke wisely how, understand well,
Suspect not, feare not

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You have brought me comfort

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: If you thinke me worthy of your Husband,
I am no rogue, nor Begger if you dare doe thus—

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You are Mounsier Cleremont,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I am the same
If you dare venture, speake, if not I leave you,
And leave you to the mercy of these villaines
That will not wooe ye much,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Save my reputation,
And free me from these slaves.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: By this kisse I'll doe it
And from the least dishonour they dare aime at you
I have a priest too, shall be ready.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You are forward,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Is this my constant Cousen? how she whispers,
Kisses and huggs the theif.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You ll offer nothing

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Till all be tyed
Not as I am a Gentleman

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Can you releive my Aunt too?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Not yet Mistris.
But feare nothing all shall be well away quickly
It must be done i'th moment or

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I am with yee

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I'll know now who sleepes by me, keepe your standing

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Well, go thy wayes, & thine own shame dwell with thee?
Is this the constancy she shewed the bravery
The deare love and the life, she owed her kinsmen?
O brave tongue valiant glorious woman?
Is this the noble anger you arriv'd at?
Are these the theeves you scornd the rogues you rayld at?
The scabs and scums of nature? o faire modesty,
Excellent vertue, whither art thou fled?
What hand of heaven is over us, when strong virgins
Yeild to their feares, and to their feares their fortunes?
Never beleef come neare me more, farewell wench,
A long farewell from all that ever knew thee
My turne is next,
I am resolved it comes
But in a nobler shape, ha?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Blesse yee Lady

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Indeed Sir. I had need of many blessings,
For all the houres I have had since I came here,
Have bin so many curses. How got you liberty?
For I presume you come to comfort me

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: To comfort you, and love you, 'tis most true,
My bondage was as yours, as full of bitternesse
And every hower my death.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Heaven was your comfort.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Till the last evening, sitting full of sadnesse
Wailing, sweet Mistris, your unhappy fortunes
Mine owne I had the least care of round about me,
The Captaine, and the company stood gaping,
When I began the story of my love,
To you faire Saint, and with so full a sorrow,
Followed each point, that even from those rude eyes,
That never knew what pitty meant or mercy
Ther stole downe soft relentings, take heed Mistris,
And let not such unholy hearts out doe you,
The soft plum'd god will see againe thus taken,
As men transform'd with the strange tale I told
They stood amaz'd then bid me rise and live,
Take liberty and meanes to see your person,
And wisht me prosperous in your love, wish you so,
Be wise and loving Lady, shew but you so

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O Sir, are these fit houres, to talke of love in?
Shall we make fooles of our afflictions?
Can any thing sound sweetly in mine eares,
Where all the noise of bloody horrour?
My Brother, and my Cousen, they are dead Sir,
Dead, basely dead, is this an age to foole in?
And I my self, I know not what I shall be
Yet I must thanke you and if happily
You had asked me yesterday, when these were living,
And my feares lesse, I might have hearkned to you,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Peace to your grief, I bind you to your word.

div.stage: Enter Cleremont Anabell, Beaupre, Verdoone, Charlote Nurse, the two Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How? doe you conjure?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Not to raise dreadfull apparitions, Madam,
But such as you would gladly see.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: My Brother, and nephew living?

sp.speaker: Beap.
sp.l: And both owe their lives,
To the favour of these Gentlemen,

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: Who deserve
Our service, and for us, your gracious thankes.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Which I give freely, and become a suitour,
To be hereafter more familiar. Kisse.
With such great worth and vertue,

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Ever thinke us,
Your servants Madam.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why if thou wilt needs know
How we are freed, I will discover it,
And with laconick brevity, these Gentlemen
This night incountring with those out lawes that
Yesterday made us prisoners, and as we were
Attempted by 'em they with greater courage,
(I am sure with better fortune not alone,
Guarded themselves, but forc'd the bloody thieves,
Being got betweene them, and this hellish Cave,
For safety of their lives, to fly up higher
Into the woods, all left to their possession
This save your Brother, and your nephew from
The gibbet, this redeem'd me from my Chaines,
And gave my friend his liberty this preserv'd
Your honour ready to be lost.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: But that
I know this for a ly, and that the thieves
And gentlemen, are the same men, by my practise,
Suborn'd to this he does deliver it
With such a constant brow, that I am doubtfull,
I should believe him too.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: If we did well,
We are rewarded.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Thankes but takes away
From what was freely purpos'd.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Now by this hand,
You have so cunningly discharg'd your parts,
That while we live, rest confident you shall
Command Dinant and Cleremont, nor Beaupre,
Nor Verdoone sents it: for the Ladyes, they
Were easie to be gul'd.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: 'Twas but a jest,
And yet the jest, may chance to breake our neckes
Should it be knowne.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Feare nothing.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Cleremont.
Say, what successe?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: As thou wouldst wish, 'tis done Lad,
The grove will witnesse with me, that this night,
I lay not like a blocke: but how speed you?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I yet am in suspence, devise some meanes
To get these off, and speedily.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I have it,
Come, we are dull, I thinke that the good fellowes,
Our predecessors in this place, were not
So foolish, and improvident husbands, but
'Twill yeild us meat, and wine.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Let's ransack it,
'Tis ours now, by the Law.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: How say you sweet one,
Have you an appetite?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: To walke againe
I'th Woods, if you thinke fit, rather then eate.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: A little respite prithee; nay blush not,
You aske but what's your owne, and warrantable
Monsier, Beaupre, Verdoone,
What thinke you of the motion?

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: Lead the way. Ex. Manent, Din. and Lamira.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: We follow willingly.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: When you shall thinke fit,
We will expect you.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Now be mistris of
Your promise Lady.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Twas to give you hearing.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: But that word hearing, did include a grant,
And you must make it good.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Must?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Must, and shall,
I will be fool'd no more, you had your tricks;
Made properties, of me, and of my friend;
Presum'd upon your power, and whip'd me with
The rod of mine owne dotage: doe not flatter
Your selfe, with hope, that any humane helpe
Can free you, and for ayde by miracle;
A base unthankfull woman is unworthy.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You will not force me?
Rather then enjury you
With your consent because I will torment you;
I'le make you feele the effects of abus'd love,
And glory in your torture.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Brother, Nephew,
Helpe, helpe, for heavens sake.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Teare your throat, cry lowder,
Though every leafe, these trees beare, were an Eccho,
And summond in your best friends to redeeme you,
It should be fruitlesse: 'tis not that I love you,
Or value those delights you prize so high,
That I'le enjoy you, a French crowne will buy
More sport, and a companion, to whom,
You in your best trim. are an Ethiope.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Forbeare me then.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Not so, I'll do't in spite,
And breake that stubborne disobedient will,
That hath so long held out, that boasted honour,
I will make equall with a common Whores;
The spring of Chastity, that fed your pride,
And grew into a River of vaine glory,
I will defile with mudd, the mudd of lust,
And make it lothsome even to goats.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O heaven!
No pitty sir?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: You taught me to be cruell,
And dare you thinke of mercy? I'le tell thee foole,
Those that surpriz'd thee, were my instruments,
I can plot too, good Madam, you shall find it:
And in the stead of licking of my fingers,
Kneeling, and whining like a boy new breech'd,
To get a toy forsooth, not worth an apple,
Thus make my way, and with Authority,
Command what I would have.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I am lost for ever:
Good sir, I doe confesse my fault, my grosse fault,
And yeild my selfe up, miserable guilty;
Thus kneeling, I confesse, you cannot study
Sufficient punishments, to load me with;
I am in your power, and I confesse againe,
You cannot be too cruell: if there be,
Besides the losse of my long guarded honour,
Any thing else to make the ballance even:
Pray put it in, all hopes, all helpes have left me;
I am girt round with sorrow, hell's about me,
And ravishment, the least that I can looke for,
Doe what you please.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Indeed I will doe nothing,
Nor touch, nor hurt you Lady, nor had ever
Such a lewd purpose.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Can there be such goodnesse,
And in a man so injur'd?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Be confirmed in't.
I seale it thus: I must confesse you vex'd me,
In fooling me so often, and those feares,
You threw upon me, call'd for a requitall,
Which now I have return'd, all unchast love
Dinant thus throwes away; live to man-kind,
As you have done to me, and I will honour
Your vertue, and no more thinke of your beauty.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: All I possesse, comes short of satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: No complements: the terrours of this night
Imagine, but a fearfull dreame, and so
With ease forget it: for Dinant, that labour'd
To blast your honour, is a Champion for it,
And will protect and guard it.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Tis as safe then,
As if a compleat Army undertooke it. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Do not perswade me gentle Monsier Sampson,
I am a mortall man againe, a Lawyer,
My mortall part, I have put off.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Sweet Monsier,
Let but our honours teach us.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Monsier Sampson
My honourable friend, my valiant friend,
Be but so beaten-forward my brave Clyents,
I am yours, and you are mine againe, be but so thrasht,
Receive that Castigation with a cudgell.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Which calls upon us for a Reparation.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: I have, it cost me halfe a crowne, I beare it
All over me, I beare it Monsier Sampson;
The oyles, and the old woman, that repaires to me,
To noint my beaten body.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: It concernes you,
You have bin swing'd.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Let it concerne thee too;
Goe and be beaten, speake scurvy words, as I did,
Speake to that Lion Lord, waken his anger,
And have a hundred Bastinado's, doe;
Three broken pates, thy teeth knockt out, doe Sampson,
Thy valiant armes and leggs beaten to Poultesses,
Doe silly Sampson, doe.

sp.speaker: 1 Cly.
sp.l: You wrong the gentleman,
To put him out of his right minde thus:
You wrong us, and our Causes.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Downe with him gentlemen,
Turne him, and beat him, if he breake our peace,
Then when thou hast bin Lam'd, thy small guts perisht,
Then talke to me, before I scorne thy counsell,
Feele what I feele, and let my Lord repaire thee.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: And can the brave La-writ—

sp.speaker: 2 Cly.
sp.l: Tempt him no further,
Be warn'd and say no more.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: If thou doest, Sampson,
Thou seest my Mirmidons, I'le let 'em loose,
That in a moment—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I say nothing, sir, but I could wish—

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: They shall destroy thee wishing;
There's ne'r a man of these, but have lost ten Causes,
Dearer then ten mens lives; tempt, and thou diest:
Goe home, and smile upon my Lord, mine Uncle,
Take Money of the men thou meanest to Cozen,
Drinke Wine, and eat good meat, and live discreetly,
Talke little, 'tis an Antidote against a beating;
Keep thy hand from thy sword, and from thy Laundresse placket,
And thou wilt live long.

sp.speaker: 1 Cly.
sp.l: Give eare, and be instructed.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I find I am wiser then a Justice of Peace now,
Give me the wisdome that's beaten into a man
That sticks still by him: art thou a new man?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Yes, yes,
Thy learned precepts have inchanted me,

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Goe my son Sampson, I have now begot thee,
I'le send thee causes; speake to thy Lord, and live.
And lay my share by, goe and live in peace,
Put on new suites, and shew fit for thy place;
That man neglects his living, is an Asse: Exit. Samp.
Farewell; come chearly boyes, about our businesse,
Now welcome tongue againe, hang Swords.

sp.speaker: 1 Cly.
sp.l: Sweet Advocate. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: I know not wench, they may call'em what they wil,
Outlawes, or theeves, but I am sure, to me
One was an honest man, he us'd me well,
What I did, 'tis no matter, he complain'd not.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I must confesse, there was one bold with me too,
Some coy thing, would say rude, but 'tis no matter,
I was to pay a Waiting womans ransome,
And I have don't, and I would pay't againe,
Were I taine to morrow

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Alas, there was no hurt,
If't be a sin, for such as live at hard meat,
And keepe a long Lent, in the woods as they doe,
To tast a little flesh,

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: God help the Courtiers,
That ly at racke and manger

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: I shall love
A theefe the better for this while I live,
They are men of a charitable vocation,
And give where there is need, and with discretion,
And put a good speed penny in my purse,
That has bin empty twenty yeares,

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Peace Nurse,
Farewell, and cry not rost meate, me thinkes Cleremont
And my Lady Anabell are in one night,
Familliarly acquainted.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: I observe it,
If she have got a penny too.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: No more,
My Lord Mounsier Vertaigne the provost too,
Hast and acquaint my Lady, Exit Nurse and Charl.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Wonderous strainge,

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: 'Tis true Sir, on my credit,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: On mine honour,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I have bin provost-Marshall twenty yeares,
And have trussed up a thousand of these rascalls,
But so nere Paris yet, I never met with,
One of that Brotherhood.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: We to our cost have,
But will you search the wood

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: It is beset,
They cannot scape us, Nothing makes me wonder,
So much as having you within their power
They let you goe; it was a Courtesy,
That French theeves use not often, I much pitty
The Gentle Ladyes, yet I know not how,
I rather hope then feare
sp.stage: Enter Dinant, Cleremont, Verdoone, Beaupre, Lamira, Anabell, Charlote, Nurse.
sp.l: Are these the prisoners?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: We were such

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Kill me not, excesse of joy,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I see thou livest, but hast thou had no fowle play

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: No on my soule, my usage hath bin noble,
Far from all violence,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: How were you freed,
But kisse me first, wee'll talk of that at leasure,
I am glad I have thee; Neice how you keepe off,
As you knew me not?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Sir, I am where
I owe most duty

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: 'Tis indeed most true Sir,
The man that should have bin your bed fellow
Your Lordships Bedfellow, that could not smell out
A Virgin of sixteene, that was your foole,
To make you merry, this poore simple fellow
Has met the maid agen, and now she knowes,
He is a man,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: How! is she dishonoured?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Not unlesse marriage be dishonourable,
Heaven is a witnesse of our happy contract
And the next Priest we meete shall warrant it
To all the world: I lay with her in jeast,
'Tis turn'd to earnest now.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Is this true Neice

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Her blushing silence grants it; nay Sir storme not
He is my friend, and I can make this good,
His birth and fortunes equall hers, your Lordship
Might have sought out a worse we are all friends too,
All differences end thus. Now Sir, unlesse
You would raise new dissentions make perfect
What is so well begun

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: That were not manly,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Let me perswade you,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Well God give you joy,
She shall not come a Begger to you Sir,
For you Monsieur Dinant 'ere long I'll shew you,
Another Neico, to this not much inferiour,
As you shall like proceed

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I thanke you Sir,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Backe then to Paris, well that travell ends
That makes of deadly enemies perfect friends.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: TO promise much, before a play begin,
And when 'tis done, aske pardon, were a sinne
Wee'll not be guilty of: and to excuse
Before we know a fault were to abuse
The writers and our selves, for I dare say
We all are foold if this be not a Playe
And such a play as shall, (so should playes doe)
Impe times dull wings, and make you merry too
'Twas to that purpose writ, so we intend it
And we have our wisht ends, if you commend it.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: I Am sent forth to enquire what you decree
Of us and our Poets, they will be
This night exceeding merry, so will we
If you approve their labours. They professe
You are their patrons, and we say no lesse,
Resolve us then, for you can onely tell
Whither we have done id'ly or done well.
